channel.title: yudel tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from yudel.

item.description: @DBashIdeas Natan Sharansky and Elie Wiesel, obviously.

On the plus side, by embracing “No Labels,” my congressman — who accused me of spreading antisemitic tropes for questioning him — has forfeited the “Vote Blue / No matter who” claim for my vote. https://t.co/XMEWdnpHTq
Come for the blistering media critique, stay for the cat picture. https://t.co/AuaFWYOjW2
Speaking of taking the name of God in vain…. (Referring to the quoted elected officials, not the Reverend.) https://t.co/nwOcLIRPSU

Orthodox Judaism is long overdue to have a halachic reckoning of how one should treat gentiles who claim to have directly heard the Word of God. https://t.co/MILT6oR9p8
Traditional accommodations, as documented by @kavvanah, have assumed other religions operated under a structure and tradition.
The average Christian, Muslim, or Hindu practitioner isn’t making a direct theological claim as they live their religious life. They are serving God in their traditional manner.
But the new breed of Christians beloved by the Fifth Circuit Court and the Republican Party say: “God told me yesterday to not get vaccinated.”
That’s a claim about who God talks to — and its a new revelation.
And it’s one that the Republican Party believes should supersede all public health measures.
@RokhlK The funny thing is that it’s a Diaspora Jewish concept — one that makes little sense in modern or ancient Israel.
@elivalley Nuclear war means never facing deadline pressur again, so I certainly relate.
@trekonomics Not only autocrats, adds the newly minted expert in the Suez Crisis (thank you Wikipedia!)
@JillPantozzi As long as neither the employer and the employee are US-based, I can’t see how the IRS could object….
@prof_dainy On the other hand, an argument for bringing “Doykeit” into the American political lexicon.
@prof_dainy Tzvee, however…. https://t.co/5GlW7OJHYt

Counterpoint: https://t.co/xWJST8WS4Y https://t.co/1hmtRreF5I
https://t.co/xWJST8WS4Y
Fixed it for you: "Netanyahu, under whose watch and guidance Iran grew closer than ever to assembling a nuclear device, accuses...." https://t.co/saKGsPEN2e
@melnickjeffrey1 Yes. But notwithstanding, Marilyn Monroe should have married Henry Miller. https://t.co/dDAAoAuoCT

So a passing historical reference sent me down the amazing, if a bit under-edited, rabbit hole that is the Wikipedia entry on the Suez Crisis. What I had thought was simply an Arab-Israeli war I knew very little about turned out to be a pivot in European and global history. 1/2
And, quite relevant to the present moment, it involved lots of highly placed people making rather poor judgements as to the consequences of their actions. 2/3 https://t.co/7eaDHKDIXm
Oh, yes, it also included a bit of Russian nuclear braggadocio. Lots of alternate history possibilities with '57 as a pivot. https://t.co/7eaDHKDIXm

@trekonomics Ask yourself: Are we feeling lucky? And does this Russian love his children two? (or perhaps three?) https://t.co/hXwrFQfCQB
@trekonomics Anyway, we already have a soundtrack for the worst case scenario.... https://t.co/9X2py5GQGD
@trekonomics Putin and his allies aren’t surrounding them on three sides.
@LeavittAlone @cstross Counterpoint: https://t.co/Y4ALs3OkGR
Not sure which is cooler: Newly discovered Hebrew epitaphs (with German translation and commentary) or seeing them served via ancient cgi-bin web protocol. https://t.co/1RihsQDKzs
@rmneiss This from last week may also be relevant: https://t.co/sCgJiDxk54
@cstross @rcarmo “Programming Prion Computers” however….
@noa_i_guess_ @KingAhav @DBashIdeas Which essay was that? (I have the book in my unread pile.)
@trekonomics One has to assume that what the original may lack in rhymes, it makes up for in fricatives
@GlennF The goal is just to constantly have sound bites in their heads so they won’t accidentally come to start thinking.
This is not the week for that, my friend. https://t.co/XcxsJ39vyu
